clean_story:
"Playing cards. Toy factories. Video game empires.
Nintendo’s name means ‘leave luck to heaven’—a nod to its 1889 start as a handmade hanafuda card company.
Back then, it was like a family printing colorful paper cards for a gambling game.
By the 1960s, Nintendo shifted to toys—selling a love tester (a battery-powered gadget that ‘measured’ affection) and an extending arm that grabbed distant objects.
Failure taught them: cheap, simple ideas could outlast flashy gimmicks.
In 1977, they tried video games with the Color TV-Game—a console that only played Pong clones.
Then came Donkey Kong (1981), a barrel-dodging game starring Jumpman—later renamed Mario.
Their secret? Repurposing old tech.
The Game Boy (1989) used a weak processor but lasted 30+ hours on 4 AA batteries—unlike rivals that died in 5.
Even the Wii (2006) bet on motion controls over graphics, selling 100M+ units.
Nintendo’s rule: Fun first, power second.
Now they guard Mario, Zelda, and Pokémon like crown jewels—licensing them only to themselves.
Their oldest card decks still sell in Japan.
Adaptation without abandoning roots.
Game design as storytelling.
How toys become legends. "
